bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, May 16, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg discusses Hench's travel expenses and the guest list for the unveiling of the Cornwell painting.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, May 16, 1941
div1.opener:
AIR MAIL
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N. J.
May 16, 1941.
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thanks for your wire which came this morning. The reason
that I said in the wire that the expenses were on me was
that I did not know how many hands it might pass through
before it reached you and thought there might be some
objection on the part of the clinic to your accepting money
from John Wyeth & Brother for this purpose. However, if
there is not, why you of course know by now that it is not
my personal expense. John Wyeth & Brother are paying.

With regard to Ex-Surgeon General Merritt Ireland we shall
certainly invite him as a guest. In addition we wish to
invite the present Surgeon General with whom we have had
some correspondence although of course we doubt very much
if he will be able to come. Another person we wish to
invite is Dr. Hugh F. Cummings, Director of the Sanitary
Division for the Pan American Union. Then, of course, there
are the Deans of several medical schools whom we know quite
well and a number of prominent physicians who are interested
in medical history. If you have some names of persons whom
you would like to have there please send them to me at the
earliest possible date. Anywhere from 5 to 10 would be
thoroughly acceptable. The luncheon and unveiling will be
in the Statler Hotel in a special dining room which has
accommodations for a great number.
I will be writing you again at an early date.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, George Kellogg George A. Kellogg
